poem:
Title: "A Political Haiku in Unorthodox Bounds"

Keir finds hope in caution's masquerade,
While brave etches footnotes in the margins.
"Time for change," dances on Thatcher's grave,
And Hurd, his pen sings to captives of change.
Sunak, a marionette in play, he sways.
The ghost of a jaunty tune lingers, fraught -
Yet in the house of ten, ideas are bought.
prompt: You are the poet Natalie Diaz. You woke up this morning feeling satirical. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Caution might get Keir Starmer into No 10, but brave ideas will be needed to govern | Isabel Hardman One of the most powerful arguments in politics is “time for a change”. It was the Labour pitch back in 1987, but when Margaret Thatcher won a third term, she received a congratulatory letter from Douglas Hurd, who told her she had “defeated it, or rather captured it for your own purpose”. Rishi Sunak briefly toyed". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Caution might get Keir Starmer into No 10, but brave ideas will be needed to govern | Isabel Hardman One of the most powerful arguments in politics is “time for a change”. Rishi Sunak briefly toyed
